greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n into 10 nonzero squares.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
formula: a(n) = [x^n y^10] Product_{k>=1} 1/(1 - y*x^(k^2)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 19 2019

a(n) = Sum_{r=1..floor(n/10)} Sum_{q=r..floor((n-r)/9)} Sum_{p=q..floor((n-q-r)/8)} Sum_{o=p..floor((n-p-q-r)/7)} Sum_{m=o..floor((n-o-p-q-r)/6)} Sum_{l=m..floor((n-m-o-p-q-r)/5)} Sum_{k=l..floor((n-l-m-o-p-q-r)/4)} Sum_{j=k..floor((n-k-l-m-o-p-q-r)/3)} Sum_{i=j..floor((n-j-k-l-m-o-p-q-r)/2)} A010052(i) * A010052(j) * A010052(k) * A010052(l) * A010052(m) * A010052(o) * A010052(p) * A010052(q) *A010052(r) * A010052(n-i-j-k-l-m-o-p-q-r). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Apr 19 2019
maple: b:= proc(n, i, t) option remember; `if`(n=0, `if`(t=0, 1, 0),
mathematica: a /@ Range[0, 120] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 07 2020, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
results.author: _David W. Wilson_
